importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the latest update on the flood situation in Mexico, showing the ongoing impact and response efforts as of this point in time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred last week, with the most intense rainfall and damage reported during that period, particularly on Wednesday.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Another 65 people are still missing, with 43 missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some homes near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla) at 280mm and 286mm respectively.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed, with the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard jointly responding to distribute food and clean water.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply to about 263,000 affected users.
Governors and national authorities, including President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, have coordinated emergency response efforts.
Mexico's meteorological alert system failed to predict the magnitude of rainfall, raising questions about early warning capabilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding across five Mexican states—primarily Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla—resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively. Over 100,000 homes were affected, and thousands of military personnel were deployed to deliver food, water, and medical aid. Despite emergency efforts, the national alert system failed to predict the magnitude of the rainfall, raising concerns about disaster preparedness. Electricity services were largely restored, with nearly 400 repair workers restoring over 80% of the power supply to approximately 263,000 users.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
